data.title: createStatusbarItem can not run "workbench.action.files.saveAll" command
Add command to move cursor to within the visible area of the viewport

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Feature request: Add a keyboard bind-able command to move to cursor to somewhere within (i.e. maybe the top or middle) the visible portion of the viewport.

I often navigate code by scrolling using `ctrl+up/down`. Once I've found the location I'm looking for the cursor is often by now off screen. The most convenient way presently available to then move the cursor to the desired location (i.e. somewhere around the middle of the viewport) is to note the desired line number and then use `ctrl+g`.

The desired feature would be a single keyboard bind-able command that moves the cursor so that it would then be within the visible area of the code editor.

data.title: .jsbeautifyrc for default VSCode beautification
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
**1.7.1**
- OS Version:
10.12.1

Looking to get the base .jsbeautifyrc file for VSCode.  I promise I looked all over the web: stackoverflow, this repo, vscode docs, my girlfriend and I even asked my parents but they had no idea :)

Anyone have a copy of the base `.jsbeautifyrc` that VSCode uses under the hood?  I'd like to build on top of what comes out of the box, but it's hard when I cant quite figure out how the code formatting is going down. 

If anyone can point me to the source where thats happen that would be awesome too.  

I swear I'm not being lazy, I've looked through the repo and the only files that make any sense are these:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/format/common/formatActions.ts#L44-L70

data.title: Auto complete guided by remote ipython server
data.body: It would be great if we can develop simple *nix python programs in our windows PC. I'm working on Tensorflow, it has a good web based support via jupyter notebook and tensorboard. But they are not good enough for develop. I can access .py files in *nix system from VS Code in windows PC, but missing auto complete since I can not install TensorFlow on windows.

data.title: [css] provide class names as workspace symbols

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: any
- OS Version: any

Hey all! Really starting to like VSCode over Sublime. Slow going but I'm getting there! 

One thing I really, really miss is goto anything, particularly as it pertains to sass / css writing.  In Sublime, I just do `goto anything`, and start typing the css classname I'm looking to edit and it brings instances of that selector in all files. Really handy for front-enders like me.

Appreciated!

data.title: Windows 10: Jump list no longer shows entries once you removed a single entry from "Recent Folders"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14959
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-css-formatter|aeschli|0.0.2|
|vs-code-css-comments|ashhitch|1.0.2|
|python|donjayamanne|0.5.0|
|vscode-html-css|ecmel|0.0.30|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|0.0.11|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.3.4|
|auto-rename-tag|formulahendry|0.0.7|
|csharpextensions|jchannon|1.0.9|
|format-php|Kasik96|1.1.2|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.9.2|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|theme-railscasts|PaulOlteanu|1.0.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|3.0.8|
|elise|schematrix|0.0.1|
|theme-tinaciousdesign|tinaciousdesign|0.1.1|

---
I moved files from one directory to a whole new directory, so I removed all the recently opened folders because they all led to blank files, made sense as the paths didn't exist any longer but vscode did make the folders. Anyway, I removed them all and now when I open any and every folder in the new directory, nothing ever shows up under recently opened no matter what I do. Only blank windows with a blank untitled file shows up :(

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Remove from recently opened
2. Nothing comes back even if different directories.

data.title: JavaScript Syntax Highlight: RegExp literals improperly parsed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44)
- OS Version: Linux Mint 17.2 (Ubuntu 14.04)

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. In a JavaScript file, type a statement containing a division operation (`/`) followed by a RegExp literal (`/.*/`) as part of the same statement e.g. `var v = (a / b).toString().match(/\d*(\.\d+)?/)`
2. The code highlighter does not highlight the statement properly e.g. in the example provided in step 1, the code highlighter thinks that the `/` in `a / b` is where the RegExp literal `/\d*(\.\d+)?/` starts from and highlights the whole `/ b).toString().match(/\d*(\.\d+)?/` part one RegExp literal.
3. The same behaviour does not exhibit if the RegExp precedes a division operator in a similar fashion, e.g. in the statement `var v = parseFloat(s.match(/\d*(\.\d+)?/).toString(), 10) / 2.5`, the same RegExp literal is highlighted properly.

**Example:** (recreated from the "Steps to Reproduce" section)
![20160111-06-16060158-9091](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4042217/20034648/9d651f02-a3e6-11e6-9a14-f010339b3437.png)

**Another example:** (this one is caught in the wild, free-range and organic)
![20160911-06-16060950-4ea9](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4042217/20034666/d7f20968-a3e7-11e6-81ef-bc6776df1242.png)

Please forgive the obscene, blasphemic JavaScript in the above example(s?). The point is, it's syntactically valid. Also, in my experience, this did not happen before the recent VSCode upgrade to 1.7.1 so I'm presuming this relates to something that was changed in 1.7.1.

data.title: Allow to shrink tabs instead of keeping a minimum width
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.6, Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open many files in the same editor until there are more tabs (per file) than can fit in the editor's tabbar real estate.

Once filled, the tabbar enables horizontal scrolling to see hidden tabs to the left/right. That's really not user friendly... and it's especially frustrating when splitting the main window into 3 editors, and then opening multiple files in each editor.

I think having a workbench setting to choose between this scroll-based tabbar behavior and a new behavior where the tabs would "compress" (i.e. begin to reduce the horizontal width of all tabs in the related editor such that less of the file's name is visible in each tab until only the close "x" button is visible per tab) would be a welcome addition to tab management.

data.title: .gitignore file not visible in file explorer
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:46.244Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-45-generic

|---|---|---|

|python|donjayamanne|0.3.24|
|vscode-exec-node|miramac|0.1.4|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a directory with .gitignore file inside
2. .gitignore is not visible in file explorer
3. Go to File > type `.gitignore`
4. .gitignore is displayed in suggestions list
5. Select .gitgnore file,  it opens in the editor and appears in file explorer

Using default _files.exclude_.

data.title: Hitting CTRL + S to save a file wont change "dirty" icon in the file TAB.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:00.226Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 15.5.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-JS-CSS-HTML-formatter|lonefy|0.2.1|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any file (tested with HTML and JS , but dont think it matters)
2. Make any change
3. Hit CTRL + S, the file is saved (can be checked externally .. it really saves the content)
4. VS Code wont change the circle icon (dirty) of that file
5. Hit CTRL + S AGAIN, the icon backs to normal "x"

Also, if you try to close the file it keeps nagging "Its not saved, are you sure ..."

[vscode-bug-save.mov.zip](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/files/573357/vscode-bug-save.mov.zip)

data.title: Gutter could not be themed
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
1.7.1
02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44
- OS Version:
Linux nohomey 4.4.0-45-generic #66-Ubuntu SMP Wed Oct 19 14:12:37 UTC 2016 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  Try to style gutter like in the [Kimbie dark theme](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/be2143ddcb6bbc27bb2f04c04ecc308c1495fa0f/extensions/theme-kimbie-dark/themes/Kimbie_dark.tmTheme#L25-L37)

I used the following code:

```xml
<key>gutterSettings</key>
<dict>
    <key>background</key>
    <string>#ffffff</string>
    <key>divider</key>
    <string>#b3b3b3</string>
    <key>foreground</key>
    <string>#b3b3b3</string>
</dict>
```

But the gutter keeps beeing light blue:
![gutter](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8791438/20031803/0a64a110-a386-11e6-809b-0b1d3fee083c.png)

data.title: Format using custom keybinding no longer working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1

- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14959.rs_prerelease.161026-1700

Steps to Reproduce:

1.     { "key": "ctrl+e d", "command": "editor.action.format" }
2.  Use keycombo to format document

This worked in 1.6, stopped working in  @1.7.1.

I can make it work using editor.action.formatDocument, but I would expect the old command also still to work. (Or make it clear to the user they need to replace the old command as it no longer works)

data.title: [themes] Latest update makes syntax highlighting too intensive
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-theme-onedark|akamud|0.2.10|
|theme-onedark|azemoh|0.3.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.0.8|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.5.4|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.4.1|

---

One of my favourite parts of VSCode is the unobtrusive syntax highlighting. The only things that were highlighted were what was needed, making code very easy to read.

However, now it seems VSCode is trying to copy other IDEs such as Atom and Sublime Text, throwing colour absolutely everywhere. This makes reading my own code incredibly confusing, as I don't know what is what anymore.

Example:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1059362/20030877/839f3e12-a333-11e6-9434-357c738ed7d6.png)

Is there a way to revert to the old syntax highlighting scheme?

data.title: Allow for floating and/or movable sidebar views
data.body:
I'm using VS Code for a while (since 1.0 or so) and sometimes it's quite annoying that multiple sidebar views can't be used at once.

Most notable issue is that debugger view too tight and it's necessary to expand it every time. But then editor window becoming too narrow.
At the same time it's completely useless to have such wide view for explorer, git or search.
So, You have to drag or toggle sidebar every time when you need to debug.
If you have monitor that something less than 1080p it leads to real problems in usability.

The best solution in my opinion is to make at least debugger view detachable. Such approach is very convenient to use with dual-monitor configuration.

Other solution is to optionally move this watcher view to bottom panel where debug console located. Maybe it'll hard to use with debug console at the same time but JetBrains IDEs uses similar layout and it works fine.

data.title: Suggestion: Line selection Count
data.body:
When selecting the lines within the file, a small count should appear along side the selected characters (bottom right hand corner) to display the amount of lines you have selected in your current like in some other popular text editors. 

Thanks,
